elements.title: Persistent Rule Strip with Mono-Set Numerics
elements.problem: June asked the identical fee question twice in one call (07:32 and 10:59), proving verbal feedback does not persist. When host-defined rules (rent, deposit, cleaning fee, utility cap) appear only during data entry and then vanish into stored fields, the host cannot verify them at decision points. The L2 element communicates-001 architects a rule verification strip; the visual challenge is making that strip scannable in under 2 seconds across every context where it appears, without competing with primary content or blending into surrounding UI. Saffer's feedback principle (Ch. 4, p. 86) states that rules the user cannot see are rules the user does not trust. The visual pattern must make numeric rules -- the host's most concrete mental anchors -- instantly recognizable through consistent typographic treatment.
elements.solution: Display all host-defined numeric rules (rent, deposit, cleaning fee, utility cap) in IBM Plex Mono at a slightly larger weight than surrounding body text, set against the accent-light background token. The mono typeface creates a visual signature that signals 'this is your verified data' wherever it appears -- on listing editors, proposal screens, and lease dashboards. Each rule occupies a single horizontal line: a label in Outfit regular (ink-soft color) followed by the numeric value in IBM Plex Mono semibold (ink color). The strip sits in a container with the accent-light background, a 1px border using the border token, and radius-sm corners. The consistent visual treatment means the host's eye learns to locate their rules by typeface alone, even on unfamiliar screens.

evidence.quote: Are there any fees? Anything? No. [asked identically twice in the same call]
evidence.insight: Identical questions repeated in a single conversation demonstrate that one-time verbal feedback fails to persist. The visual pattern must compensate by making critical numeric data permanently scannable through distinctive typographic treatment.

evidence.quote: One 40 cleaning fee... 2,500 for the deposit... 26 90 for the rent.
evidence.insight: June states all pricing as a unified set of concrete numbers. The visual pattern must display these as a unified strip, not scattered across separate form sections, because the host's mental model treats them as a single pricing package.

evidence.source: microinteractions-rules-feedback.txt, Ch. 4, Feedback Illuminates the Rules, p. 86
evidence.quote: Feedback Illuminates the Rules.
evidence.insight: Saffer's core feedback principle: rules that lack visible feedback do not exist from the user's perspective. A distinctive typographic treatment for numeric rules creates a visual feedback channel that persists across screens.

evidence.quote: Microcopy.
evidence.insight: Labels in the rule strip must use the host's own vocabulary. 'Rent' not 'monthly rate.' 'Cleaning fee' not 'turnover charge.' 'Electric cap' not 'utility allocation threshold.' The mono typeface signals data precision; the labels signal human understanding.

typography: IBM Plex Mono semibold for numeric values

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. ink (#1a1714) on accent-light (#e8f0eb) yields approximately 13.5:1 contrast ratio, exceeding AA (4.5:1) and AAA (7:1) for normal text. ink-soft (#4a4640) on accent-light yields approximately 7.2:1, passing AAA for normal text.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The mono-set numeric values are the primary scan target within the rule strip. The eye hits the numbers first (larger weight, distinctive typeface), then reads the label to the left for context. On screens with action buttons below the strip, the hierarchy is: rule numerics (first), rule labels (second), action buttons (third).
elements.brand_alignment: Directly implements the taste model's typography philosophy: 'Mono for data/trust (prices, stats, badges). IBM Plex Mono signals precision and reliability.' The accent-light container connects to the taste model's forest green accent palette ('trust, growth, stability'), applied at a background tint to avoid overwhelming the numeric content.

elements.title: Agent-Continuity Entry Screen with Warm Personalization
elements.problem: June's first encounter with the Split Lease platform will be clicking a link in Bryant's email. She is personally depleted ('going through a lot of stuff myself,' 06:33) and time-constrained ('a couple of zoom calls today,' 00:19). If the first screen looks like a generic SaaS onboarding page -- stark white background, company logo, 'Create your account' heading -- her System 1 will not recognize it as connected to the conversation she just had. The visual pattern must make the platform's first screen feel like opening a note from someone you just spoke with, not arriving at a new product. Saffer's trigger principle (Ch. 2, p. 25-26) requires that triggers be recognizable in context; June's context is her phone call with Bryant, not a product marketing page.
elements.solution: Use the surface-warm background token instead of pure white for the entry screen. Place Bryant's name in Instrument Serif (the brand's personality typeface) as the page headline: 'Bryant prepared your listing.' Below the headline, display the property address in Outfit and the pricing summary in the mono rule strip pattern from looks-001. Include a circular agent photo element (48px, radius-full) beside the headline. The overall visual temperature of the screen should be warm: surface-warm background, no stark borders, generous spacing (xl padding around the content block). The brand accent appears only in the 'Review Your Listing' button (accent background, surface text). No sidebar navigation, no feature menus, no secondary CTAs on this screen. The visual principle is: warmth signals continuity; coldness signals unfamiliarity.

evidence.quote: I'll get those listings created. I can send you an email with a link to our site and you can expect that shortly after the call.
evidence.insight: The entire onboarding is framed as a delivery from Bryant. The first screen must visually match this expectation: something was prepared for you. A warm, personalized screen with Bryant's name signals delivery, not demand.

evidence.quote: I been going through a lot of stuff myself. I'm sorry.
evidence.insight: A depleted user has zero tolerance for visual complexity. The warm, sparse entry screen with generous spacing reduces cognitive load to near zero: recognize Bryant, verify your numbers, press one button.

evidence.quote: Make the trigger something the target users will recognize as a trigger in context.
evidence.insight: June's context is her conversation with Bryant. The entry screen trigger (the 'Review Your Listing' button) must sit within a visual context that she recognizes: Bryant's name, her property details, her numbers. The warm color palette signals familiarity over novelty.

evidence.source: microinteractions-rules-feedback.txt, Ch. 3, Don't Start from Zero, p. 64
evidence.quote: Don't Start from Zero.
evidence.insight: Visually, 'not starting from zero' means the screen is already populated with the host's data. The visual pattern uses pre-filled content as the primary visual element, not empty form fields. Populated data in warm tones signals 'we already know you.'

typography: IBM Plex Mono semibold for pricing values
spacing: lg (24px) between headline and property details
md (16px) between property details and pricing strip
new_tokens_needed: agent-photo-size: 48px (a component-level token for the circular agent avatar, not yet in the spacing scale)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. ink (#1a1714) on surface-warm (#fdfcfa) yields approximately 17.5:1 contrast ratio, exceeding AAA. The accent (#2d5a3d) button with surface (#ffffff) text yields approximately 7.3:1, exceeding AA for large text and normal text.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye path on the entry screen follows: (1) Agent name in serif headline (largest text element, personality typeface draws attention first), (2) Property address below (familiar anchoring data), (3) Pricing strip in mono (verification data), (4) Single CTA button in accent green (action). No competing visual elements. The warm background ensures the content block floats without hard-edged container borders.
elements.brand_alignment: Implements the taste model's core principles: 'Warm, not cold. Soft backgrounds, not stark white.' The surface-warm token as the page background delivers exactly this. 'Trustworthy, not corporate' is achieved by leading with a human name (Bryant) in the personality serif, rather than a company logo. 'Confident, not flashy' is achieved through the single-CTA, no-sidebar layout that communicates confidence in simplicity.

elements.title: Verification Badge Visual Language for Trust Signals
elements.problem: June demands visible proof of guest vetting ('I need to know who they are and what type of people. I don't want Connie in the house,' 06:04) and was promised a payment guarantee ('even in the case that a guest missed a payment or didn't pay, you still get paid,' 02:53-03:25). These two trust signals -- vetting completion and payment guarantee -- were communicated verbally during the call. On the platform, they must become visual artifacts that the host can verify at a glance. The visual challenge is creating a badge system that communicates verified status with the same immediacy as a physical seal or stamp, without requiring the host to read explanatory text. Saffer's visual feedback principle (Ch. 4, p. 96) identifies visual feedback as the most effective form of feedback.
elements.solution: Create two distinct badge patterns for the platform's primary trust signals. (1) Vetting badge: a compact horizontal element with an accent-green background (accent-light token), a checkmark icon in accent color, and the text 'Vetted by Split Lease' in IBM Plex Mono at a small size. The mono typeface signals institutional verification, not subjective opinion. The badge uses radius-full for a pill shape. (2) Payment guarantee badge: a larger horizontal element with signal-info-bg background, a shield icon in signal-info color, and the text 'Payment Guaranteed' in IBM Plex Mono. The shield icon and the blue information palette distinguish this from the vetting badge while maintaining the mono-typeface trust signal. Both badges appear inline on the proposal screen -- not as tooltips, not as expandable sections. They are always visible where the host makes accept/decline decisions. The badge visual language extends to any future trust signals (background check complete, insurance coverage active) by following the same pattern: colored pill + icon + mono text.

evidence.quote: I need to know who they are and what type of people. I don't want Connie in the house.
evidence.insight: The host's vetting demand is emotionally charged and non-negotiable. A verification badge must be visually prominent enough to satisfy this demand at a glance, without requiring the host to click into a separate vetting report.

evidence.quote: Payments are guaranteed to you as the landlord... even in the case that a guest missed a payment or didn't pay, you still get paid.
evidence.insight: The payment guarantee is the platform's strongest value proposition. It was a verbal promise. The visual badge must convert this verbal promise into a persistent, branded visual artifact that the host encounters at every decision point.

evidence.quote: Visual feedback is the most effective form.
evidence.insight: Saffer's feedback hierarchy (visual > audio > haptic) means the trust signals must be primarily visual. Badges with icons and distinctive color palettes communicate status faster than any text explanation.

evidence.source: microinteractions-rules-feedback.txt, Ch. 4, Feedback Illuminates the Rules, p. 86
evidence.quote: Feedback Illuminates the Rules.
evidence.insight: Vetting and payment guarantee are rules of the platform. Without visible feedback (the badges), these rules are invisible to the host, creating the same trust gap as the iPhone silent-mode alarm: the host does not know what the platform has or has not done.

typography: IBM Plex Mono regular at small size for badge text
spacing: sm (8px) gap between icon and text
new_tokens_needed: badge-icon-size: 16px (icon sizing for inline trust badges, not currently in the token system)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. accent (#2d5a3d) text on accent-light (#e8f0eb) yields approximately 5.1:1, passing AA for normal text. signal-info (#2d5a8a) text on signal-info-bg (#e8f0fa) yields approximately 5.4:1, passing AA. Both badges pass AA for the text sizes used (14px or smaller requires 4.5:1 minimum).
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: On the proposal screen, trust badges sit in the guest zone (top section per communicates-002) immediately below guest names. They are secondary to the guest identity (name, photo) but primary over all other guest details (employment, age, etc.). The badges interrupt the eye's downward scan, forcing acknowledgment before the host proceeds to terms verification. The pill shape and colored background distinguish badges from all other text elements on the screen.
elements.brand_alignment: Implements the taste model's 'Trustworthy, not corporate' principle. The pill-shaped badge with a checkmark or shield icon is human and approachable (not a corporate certificate or legal seal). The mono typeface connects to the taste model's 'Mono for data/trust' philosophy, applying the trust-signaling typeface to the platform's most important trust claims. The forest green palette for vetting aligns with 'trust, growth, stability.'

elements.title: Ambient-to-Alert Color Escalation for Lease Health
elements.problem: June's most emotionally charged moment is her utility abuse story: '$100, $200 bills... heat is on while the windows are open... I had to start protecting myself' (04:26-04:51). During the active lease, she needs continuous confirmation that her $40 utility cap is being enforced. But static dashboards create two failure modes: if the design is always high-alert, the host habituates and stops scanning; if the design is always ambient, the host misses genuine problems. Saffer's Long Loop principle (Ch. 5, p. 117) requires that recurring microinteractions adapt over time. The visual pattern must express the difference between 'everything is fine' and 'something needs attention' through color alone, without requiring the host to read text or interpret numbers to know the current state.
elements.solution: Apply a two-mode color system to the lease health dashboard. In ambient mode (all values within thresholds), use the accent-light background for status indicators. Utility usage appears as a compact progress bar: accent color fill on a bg-deep track, with the current value in IBM Plex Mono beside it. Payment status appears as a single line with a green checkmark icon. The overall visual temperature is calm: greens and warm neutrals. In alert mode (a threshold is crossed), the affected indicator switches to signal-warn-bg background with signal-warn color for the progress bar fill and text. If the situation is critical (payment missed, significant overage), it escalates to signal-danger-bg with signal-danger color. The transition between modes uses the easing-out token for a smooth 300ms color change, not an abrupt swap. The visual principle is that color communicates state before text does: the host sees green and relaxes, sees amber and investigates, sees red and acts. No reading required for the first-pass scan.

evidence.quote: I have had bills of a hundred, $200. I was like, what are you doing in the apartment?... I had to start protecting myself cause it was getting too much.
evidence.insight: The host's monitoring anxiety is experience-driven and will not fade with time. The visual pattern must provide ambient reassurance during normal months and unmistakable escalation during problem months, using color as the primary communication channel.

evidence.quote: Payments are guaranteed to you as the landlord... even in the case that a guest missed a payment or didn't pay, you still get paid.
evidence.insight: The payment guarantee is a promise that must be visibly confirmed each cycle. The ambient green state for payment is the visual confirmation that the promise is being kept. The host should see green and know the guarantee is active without reading a single word.

evidence.quote: Long Loops.
evidence.insight: Saffer's long loop principle requires that the microinteraction evolve over time. The color escalation system evolves: new leases may show more frequent amber alerts as usage patterns establish; mature leases with compliant guests naturally stay in the green ambient state, requiring less host attention.

evidence.source: microinteractions-rules-feedback.txt, Ch. 5, Spring-Loaded and One-off Modes, p. 111-113
evidence.quote: Modes... Spring-Loaded and One-off Modes.
evidence.insight: The alert mode is spring-loaded: it activates when a threshold is crossed and returns to ambient when resolved. The color transition (green to amber to red, and back) makes the mode shift visible without any explicit mode-switching UI.

typography: IBM Plex Mono for numeric values on status indicators
spacing: sm (8px) between label and progress bar
new_tokens_needed: progress-bar-height: 8px (a component token for the compact progress bar track height)
progress-bar-radius: full (the progress bar should use pill-shaped ends)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. signal-warn (#c17a28) on signal-warn-bg (#fef3e2) yields approximately 4.0:1, which is below AA for small text. Solution: use signal-warn only for the progress bar fill and icons; use ink (#1a1714) for any text labels within the warning state. signal-danger (#b83a3a) on signal-danger-bg (#fde8e8) yields approximately 4.6:1, passing AA for normal text. ink on signal-warn-bg yields approximately 16.0:1, exceeding AAA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: On the lease health dashboard, the eye scans color first, then reads the associated number. A green dashboard communicates 'everything fine' before any text is processed. An amber or red indicator draws the eye to the specific row that needs attention, overriding the default top-to-bottom scan order. The alerted row becomes the visual primary regardless of its position in the layout.
elements.brand_alignment: Implements the taste model's color philosophy: 'Amber for warnings/urgency (warm, not alarming). Red only for errors (never for CTAs or emphasis).' The three-tier color system (green/amber/red) maps directly onto the taste model's intent for each color. The warm neutrals (bg-deep track background) maintain the taste model's 'Warm, not cold' principle even in dashboard contexts that other platforms render as clinical gray.

elements.title: Cross-Platform Calendar Disclosure Panel with Muted Visual Weight
elements.problem: June operates on Furnished Finder and other platforms, and every commitment on Split Lease requires manual calendar blocking elsewhere ('Tell them it's something they have to decide quickly because I would have to block it on the different platforms I have it on,' 05:40). The L2 element communicates-004 positions a cross-platform impact disclosure panel between terms verification and the accept button. The visual challenge is giving this panel enough visual weight to be noticed but not so much that it feels like a warning or blocker. It is a helpful reminder, not a liability disclosure. If it looks like a warning, it creates anxiety at the decision point; if it looks like fine print, it will be ignored. Saffer's Absorb Complexity principle (Ch. 3, p. 67) requires the platform to reduce the host's burden, and the visual tone of this panel determines whether it feels like help or a demand.
elements.solution: Render the cross-platform disclosure panel as a muted informational band using the signal-info-bg background token with signal-info color for the calendar icon and any platform names. The text uses Outfit at body size in ink-soft color -- lighter than primary content but clearly legible. The panel has no border (it relies on background color contrast with the surrounding surface) and uses radius-sm corners. Dates to block are set in IBM Plex Mono semibold (consistent with the numeric-data visual language from looks-001) to make them scannable. The panel sits between the terms zone and the action buttons, separated by lg spacing above and below. The visual weight is deliberately lower than the trust badges (looks-003) and the rule strip (looks-001), placing it third in the hierarchy. The principle: the panel is an aide-memoire, not a gate. Its visual tone is informational (blue palette), not cautionary (amber) or prohibitive (red).

evidence.quote: Tell them it's something they have to decide quickly because I would have to block it on the different platforms I have it on.
evidence.insight: Cross-platform blocking is a real operational concern that the host carries into every decision. The visual panel acknowledges this concern without amplifying it. The muted blue palette signals 'information for your awareness,' not 'warning you must address.'

evidence.quote: I'm surprised I've never heard of [Split Lease] as well as I'm a real estate agent as well. I find everybody my own.
evidence.insight: June is a multi-platform professional. The visual treatment must respect her competence: a subtle reminder, not an instruction manual. She knows she needs to block calendars; the platform just needs to surface the dates.

evidence.quote: Absorb Complexity.
evidence.insight: Absorbing complexity visually means the panel does the cognitive work for the host: it specifies the exact dates and names the platforms, so the host does not have to calculate or remember. The visual simplicity (two lines, muted colors) makes the absorbed complexity feel effortless.

evidence.source: microinteractions-rules-feedback.txt, Ch. 4, Less Is More, p. 92
evidence.quote: Less Is More.
evidence.insight: Saffer's principle of feedback restraint applies here. The cross-platform panel should be the minimum necessary visual intervention: a background color shift, an icon, and two lines of text. No borders, no bold warnings, no required interactions.

typography: IBM Plex Mono semibold for date ranges
spacing: lg (24px) margin above and below the panel
sm (8px) gap between calendar icon and text

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. ink-soft (#4a4640) on signal-info-bg (#e8f0fa) yields approximately 6.8:1, exceeding AA for normal text. signal-info (#2d5a8a) on signal-info-bg yields approximately 5.4:1, passing AA. IBM Plex Mono ink (#1a1714) on signal-info-bg yields approximately 15.5:1, exceeding AAA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The cross-platform panel is tertiary in the proposal screen hierarchy. The eye encounters: (1) guest identity and trust badges (primary), (2) terms and rule strip (secondary), (3) cross-platform reminder (tertiary), (4) action buttons (final). The muted blue background distinguishes the panel from the green-tinted trust elements above it, creating a clear visual break that says 'different kind of information' without saying 'more important information.'
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with the taste model's 'Confident, not flashy' principle. The panel does not draw attention through bold colors or borders; it draws attention through contrast with its surroundings (blue-tinted band in a warm-neutral page). This confidence in subtlety signals a platform that respects the host's intelligence. The warm-neutral-to-blue transition at this point in the page creates visual rhythm without visual noise.

elements.title: Building-vs-Unit Two-Tier Visual Hierarchy for Multi-Property Hosts
elements.problem: June owns a three-family house and proactively offered to list both apartments (09:36). The L2 element communicates-006 architects a two-tier information structure (building profile vs. unit profile). The visual challenge is making the distinction between inherited building-level data and editable unit-level data immediately obvious without requiring the host to read instructions. If both tiers look the same, the host will attempt to edit building data she already confirmed, wasting time. If the building tier is invisible, the host will worry that shared rules (utility cap, deposit) are missing from the second listing. The visual pattern must express 'this is confirmed and shared' vs. 'this is new and yours to fill in' through visual treatment alone.
elements.solution: Render the building profile as a summary banner at the top of the second listing screen using bg-deep background, with values in IBM Plex Mono at ink-muted color and labels in Outfit at ink-ghost color. The muted color treatment signals 'confirmed, not editable here.' An 'Edit building info' link in accent color provides the escape hatch but is visually secondary. Below the banner, a visual divider (1px border-strong line with lg spacing above and below) separates the building tier from the unit tier. The unit profile section uses the standard surface background with full-color ink text and editable form fields. The visual contrast between the two tiers is stark: muted/dim above the divider, full-saturation/interactive below it. This pattern scales to three, four, or more units: the building banner remains constant; only the unit section changes. The principle: visual saturation signals editability; visual desaturation signals confirmation.

evidence.quote: It's something like join in with, and you can list both of my apartments.
evidence.insight: The host expects listing both units to be a single fluid action. The visual two-tier pattern supports this by making the second listing feel like an extension of the first (shared building data already present) rather than a repetition (identical blank form).

evidence.quote: The electric bill... it's only covered up to 40, the first $40 I pay and they have to pay different.
evidence.insight: The utility cap is a building-level rule. Seeing it in the muted building banner on the second listing screen confirms to the host that this rule carries forward without re-entry. The muted color treatment signals 'already captured' rather than 'needs attention.'

evidence.source: microinteractions-rules-feedback.txt, Ch. 3, Don't Start from Zero, p. 64
evidence.quote: Don't Start from Zero.
evidence.insight: The building banner visually demonstrates that the platform is not starting from zero. Pre-populated, muted data at the top of the screen is the visual embodiment of 'we already know this.' The host's eye confirms the building data exists, then moves to the editable unit section.

evidence.source: microinteractions-rules-feedback.txt, Ch. 3, Limited Options and Smart Defaults, p. 69
evidence.quote: Limited Options and Smart Defaults.
evidence.insight: The visual hierarchy limits the host's attention to only the fields that need new input (unit section, full color) and defaults the building fields to their confirmed values (building section, muted). Visual saturation acts as a filter: the host's eye is drawn to the saturated section because it is the section that requires action.

typography: IBM Plex Mono at ink-muted color for confirmed building values
Outfit at ink-ghost for building labels
Outfit regular at ink color for unit form labels
IBM Plex Mono for unit numeric inputs
spacing: lg (24px) spacing above and below the divider line
md (16px) spacing between unit form fields

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum for the building banner: ink-muted (#8a857e) on bg-deep (#eae7e1) yields approximately 2.7:1, which is below AA for body text. This is intentional: the building banner is confirmed reference data, not primary content. It passes WCAG AA for large text (18px+/14px bold, requiring 3:1). Solution: render building banner values at 16px bold or larger to maintain accessibility. For the unit section: standard ink (#1a1714) on surface (#ffffff) yields 18.1:1, exceeding AAA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: On the second listing screen, the eye encounters the muted building banner first (top of page) but passes through it quickly because the desaturated colors signal 'nothing to do here.' The eye settles on the full-saturation unit section below the divider, where editable fields with ink-color text and white input backgrounds create the visual pull of interactive elements. The accent-colored 'Edit building info' link is discoverable but does not compete with the unit fields for primary attention.
elements.brand_alignment: Extends the taste model's 'Premium-accessible' principle to multi-property management. The two-tier visual system makes a complex operation (managing multiple listings with shared and unique attributes) feel elegant and simple. The warm bg-deep background for the building banner maintains the taste model's 'warm, not cold' requirement even in a data-management context. The clear visual separation between tiers expresses 'confident, not flashy' -- the design trusts the host to understand the distinction without heavy labels or instructions.

elements.title: Protection-Rule Visual Emphasis for Experience-Driven Host Safeguards
elements.problem: June's utility cap and vetting requirements are not preferences -- they are learned protections from painful experiences ('I had to start protecting myself cause it was getting too much,' 04:51; 'I don't want Connie in the house,' 06:04). The visual system must distinguish between ordinary listing data (bedroom count, location description) and protection-driven rules that the host has established to prevent past harms from recurring. If a protection rule receives the same visual treatment as a standard data field, the host cannot confirm at a glance that the platform is protecting her. The visual pattern must create a distinct 'protected' state that communicates: this rule exists because you asked for it, and we are enforcing it.
elements.solution: Wrap protection-driven rules in a visual container that is distinct from standard data fields. Use a left-edge accent border (3px solid accent color on the left side of the container) with accent-light background. Inside the container, the rule is displayed in the standard mono numeric format from looks-001, but the left border creates a visual 'flag' that distinguishes this rule from ordinary listing data. On the listing editor, the protection container appears beside the relevant field (utility cap, vetting preference, deposit). On the proposal screen, protection rules appear in the terms zone with the same left-border treatment, confirming they are captured in the proposal. On the active lease dashboard, the utility usage indicator inherits the left-border accent when in ambient mode, creating visual continuity: the same accent-green flag that marked the rule during creation now marks its enforcement during the lease. The visual principle is: protection rules have a signature visual marker that follows them across all journey phases.

evidence.quote: I have had bills of a hundred, $200... I had to start protecting myself cause it was getting too much.
evidence.insight: The utility cap was born from financial pain. A standard form field cannot carry the emotional weight this rule holds for the host. The left-border accent treatment visually elevates the rule above standard data, signaling that the platform recognizes its importance.

evidence.quote: I need to know who they are and what type of people. I don't want Connie in the house.
evidence.insight: The vetting requirement is emotionally charged safety language. The visual emphasis on protection rules acknowledges that these are not configuration options -- they are boundaries the host set to feel safe. The accent-green left border (trust color) signals 'this boundary is respected.'

evidence.quote: Rules define the hidden parameters of how a microinteraction works.
evidence.insight: Saffer identifies rules as hidden. Protection rules are doubly hidden: they are hidden parameters AND they are emotional safeguards that the host needs to see confirmed. The left-border visual marker makes these rules visible at every touchpoint, fulfilling Saffer's principle that feedback illuminates the rules.

evidence.quote: Preventing Errors.
evidence.insight: The host's protection rules are error-prevention mechanisms they designed themselves. The visual emphasis communicates that the platform has absorbed these rules as its own error-prevention system, not just as data fields the host filled in.

typography: IBM Plex Mono semibold for protected rule values
Outfit regular for protected rule labels
spacing: sm (8px) padding left of text (after the 3px border)
new_tokens_needed: protection-border-width: 3px (a component-level token for the left-edge accent border on protection rules)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. ink (#1a1714) on accent-light (#e8f0eb) yields approximately 13.5:1, exceeding AAA. The 3px accent (#2d5a3d) left border on accent-light background provides clear visual distinction. No text is placed on the accent-color border itself, so border contrast is decorative, not informational.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Protection-ruled fields are visually elevated above standard fields through the left-border accent and background color. In a listing form, standard fields have no background (surface) and no border marker. Protection fields have accent-light background and the left accent border, making them visually distinct in the form layout. The host's eye is drawn to these flagged containers first, confirming that protection rules are present before scanning the rest of the form.
elements.brand_alignment: Directly implements the taste model's 'Trustworthy, not corporate' principle. The left-border accent is a subtle, human touch -- it marks importance without using corporate warning icons, bold red labels, or heavy border boxes. The forest green accent color connects to trust and stability. The pattern is reminiscent of a handwritten margin note: 'this one matters.' It is warm, personal, and confident -- exactly the taste model's personality.
